comment.body:
I think you can change this to
```
repo = old.pname;
```

pull_request.title: Build CBMC from source and add to nix CI cache
pull_request.body:
This PR is building CBMC from sources. Right now it's pinned to the `cbmc-5.95.1` tag (https://github.com/diffblue/cbmc/commit/731338d5d82ac86fc447015e0bd24cdf7a74c442), but we can update it to other commits when needed. 

The build requires around 10 minutes on my machine and in CI.

To make this feasible in the CI, the dependency builds are cached in the Github Action Cache using https://github.com/DeterminateSystems/magic-nix-cache. This means it should only take 10 minutes once, and then consecutive builds should be as fast as loading it from the package manager. 
I tested here by re-running the CI jobs and it seems to work fine.
If we see any CI performance degradation in other PRs, I'll need to look more into the configuration of https://github.com/DeterminateSystems/magic-nix-cache

comment.body: I think you can also reference version by ${version} here

pull_request.title: Build CBMC from source and add to nix CI cache
pull_request.body:
This PR is building CBMC from sources. Right now it's pinned to the `cbmc-5.95.1` tag (https://github.com/diffblue/cbmc/commit/731338d5d82ac86fc447015e0bd24cdf7a74c442), but we can update it to other commits when needed. 

The build requires around 10 minutes on my machine and in CI.

To make this feasible in the CI, the dependency builds are cached in the Github Action Cache using https://github.com/DeterminateSystems/magic-nix-cache. This means it should only take 10 minutes once, and then consecutive builds should be as fast as loading it from the package manager. 
I tested here by re-running the CI jobs and it seems to work fine.
If we see any CI performance degradation in other PRs, I'll need to look more into the configuration of https://github.com/DeterminateSystems/magic-nix-cache

comment.body: I have no idea why the buffer need to `+2`. Does anyone know why?

pull_request.title: Add Keccak X interface
pull_request.body:
### Prototype of Keccak Interface

This module is designed for reuse in Dilithium.

### Keccak X-Ways Behavior:

1. **Input Handling**: Uses scatter-gather memory style.
2. **Output Handling**: Also uses scatter-gather memory style.

The consecutive memory assumption complicates code reuse. Minor changes to the assembly implementation may be required. Specifically, for Keccak, we load individual vector registers, which necessitates a few additional vector permutation instructions.

### Keccak Design Steps:

1. User provides data for the input lane.
2. User provides output for each lane.
3. All lanes are absorbed simultaneously.
4. All lanes are squeezed simultaneously.

### Additional APIs for Single Lane Operations:

```c
uint64_t *keccakx_get_lane_state(keccakx *kx, size_t lane_index);
```

This allows for retrieving the state of a specific lane for continued single Keccak operations.

### Optimization Potential with Scatter-Gather Memory:

- **Multiple Pass Squeezing**: Currently, if `rej_uniform` fails to sample the full vector size, it continues by squeezing a single Keccak lane. By rewriting this logic to append single Keccak calls into a single Keccak X-way call, CPU cycles can be saved. For simplicity, it is currently implemented as a single pass.

### Implementation Details:

Originally, the implementation of KeccakX used heap memory, but it has been converted to stack-only, which is more efficient.

### Next Steps:

- Add Keccak_X_Way assembly to replace the `for loop` in `fips202x.c`.

Fixes #35

comment.body:
The size of `KYBER_SYMBTES + 2` is `34`, which creates unaligned load from stack for each lane. 
I suggest make it to `KYBER_SYMBYTES + 16`. Wdyt?

offset related are completely removed. This line can't be reached. See 
https://github.com/pq-crystals/kyber/issues/74
